title: The Rememberer
description: In a world where memories can be sold, you deal in stolen ones.

scenes.title: The Client
scenes.content:
The woman across from you shivers in her rain-soaked jacket. Water drips from her hair onto the cracked vinyl booth at Mel's. Four in the morning. The neon sign outside flickers 'Open 24 Hours' but the 'H' keeps dying.

She slides a photograph across the table. Little girl with pigtails, gap-toothed smile. "My daughter. Sarah. She's twelve now."

You don't touch the photo. "What happened?"

"Car accident. Three months ago. She doesn't remember me. Doesn't remember anything before the crash." Her voice cracks. "The doctors say her hippocampus... they say she'll never make new memories stick."

The coffee tastes like burnt rubber. You've heard this story before. Different faces, same desperation. 

"I need her childhood back," she whispers. "Birthday parties, bedtime stories, Christmas mornings. I recorded everything on neural feeds before the accident. Just in case."

Smart. Most people wait until it's too late.

"The clinic won't do memory implants on minors. Says it's experimental." She leans forward. "But I know you can get around that."

choices.text: "Kid cases are complicated. My rate doubles."
"I don't work with children. Find someone else."
"Let me see the neural recordings first."

scenes.title: The Price
scenes.content:
She doesn't flinch. "How much?"

"Sixty thousand. Half up front."

Her laugh has no humor in it. "I'm a single mother working two jobs. The medical bills already cleaned me out."

You drain your coffee. Outside, someone stumbles down Sunset Boulevard, singing off-key karaoke to the empty street. Another lost soul in the city of angels.

"Then we have a problem."

"Wait." She grabs your wrist. Her fingers are ice-cold. "What if I had something else? Something valuable?"

Everything's valuable to someone. Question is what and how much.

"I work at Meridian Clinic. Memory storage facility. I have access to the premium vaults." She lowers her voice. "Celebrity memories. Politicians. Tech billionaires. Stuff worth millions on the black market."

Now she has your attention. Meridian's security makes Fort Knox look like a corner store. But inside jobs... those are different.

The waitress refills your cup without being asked. Her name tag says 'Dolores' but you remember her from a case last year. Different name then.

choices.text: "What kind of access do you have?"
"Too risky. Meridian will trace it back to you."
"I know someone who might be interested. No guarantees."

scenes.title: Walking Away
scenes.content:
You stand up and drop a five on the table. "Good luck with your daughter."

"Please." Her voice breaks. "You're my last option."

They always say that. Last option. End of the line. Like you're some kind of savior instead of what you really are. A parasite feeding off other people's pain.

The rain has stopped but the streets still gleam black under the neon. Your Corolla sits at the curb, rust eating through the wheel wells. Three more payments and it's yours.

Your phone buzzes. Text from Marcus: "Got a rush job. Celebrity suicide. Family wants the last day wiped clean before the media gets hold of it. Fifty K for clean extraction."

Easy money. No complications. No kids involved.

But as you reach for the car door, you see the woman through the diner window. Still sitting in the booth. Still staring at that photograph. Still drowning in hope she can't afford.

Your phone buzzes again. Different number this time. Unknown caller.

choices.text: Answer the unknown number
Take Marcus's job and drive away
Go back into the diner

scenes.title: The Recordings
scenes.content:
She pulls out a neural tablet. Military grade, probably worth more than your car. The screen flickers to life, showing memory fragments in fast-forward. A little girl learning to ride a bike. Same girl blowing out candles on a birthday cake. Christmas morning, wrapping paper everywhere.

But something's wrong. The neural patterns are too clean. Too perfect. Real memories have static, gaps, emotional bleeding at the edges. These look processed. Edited.

"Where did you get these?"

"I told you. I recorded them myself." But she won't meet your eyes.

You pause the playback on the birthday scene. The timestamp shows last month. Three weeks after the accident, according to her story. "This memory is from December. Your daughter's accident was in September."

Her face goes pale. "I... I must have mixed up the files."

"Try again. And this time don't lie to me."

She closes the tablet. "They're not her memories. They're mine. From when I was twelve." Her voice gets smaller. "I want to give her my childhood. The one she'll never have."

choices.text: "That's not how memory works. She'll know they're fake."
"You want to steal your daughter's identity."
"Show me the real recordings of her."

scenes.title: Inside Information
scenes.content:
"Maintenance access. I clean the storage units after each session." She pulls out an ID badge. Linda Chen, Custodial Services. "I see everything that goes in and out."

"What's the most valuable thing in there?"

"Senator Blake's war memories. Afghanistan. The stuff he's built his career on. Turns out most of it never happened. He bought combat memories from a dead Marine."

Interesting. But not worth the risk.

"There's more. Judge Morrison's childhood. Perfect family man, right? Except he has memories of burning cats alive when he was ten. And Elena Vasquez."

You know that name. Billionaire tech mogul. Pioneer in consciousness transfer technology.

"She's got memories from twelve different people. Like she's collecting identities." Linda leans closer. "Including someone who died fifty years ago. How is that possible?"

Now that's worth sixty thousand. Maybe more. But Meridian doesn't just store memories. They traffic in them. And they have friends in low places.

"Security rotation changes at midnight. Skeleton crew on weekends."

choices.text: "When's the next weekend shift?"
"Meridian has killed people for less."
"What's Elena Vasquez hiding?"

scenes.title: The Warning
scenes.content:
"Stop looking into Sarah Chen." The voice is electronically distorted. Professional grade scrambler.

"Wrong number." But you don't hang up.

"You're sitting outside Mel's Diner. Rust-orange Corolla. License plate 7-Adam-Sam-2-1-9. Should I continue?"

Your blood goes cold. You scan the street but see nothing except empty parking lots and closed storefronts. "Who is this?"

"Someone who knows what really happened to that little girl. Walk away. Tonight. Don't look back."

The line goes dead.

Through the diner window, you see Linda still clutching that photograph. Still believing in miracles. But the voice on the phone sounded certain. Confident. Like someone with unlimited resources and zero patience.

Your phone rings again. Marcus, probably wondering why you haven't taken his celebrity job. Easy money versus whatever trap you just stepped in.

But the caller knew about Sarah. Knew you were here. Which means they've been watching. The question is how long.

choices.text: Drive straight to Marcus and take his job
Go back inside and warn Linda
Call the number back

scenes.title: False Memories
scenes.content:
"She won't know anything. That's the point." Linda's desperation bleeds through every word. "Her brain is damaged. She can't form new memories. These would be all she has."

"And when she grows up? When she realizes her childhood belongs to someone else?"

"She won't grow up." The words hit like a punch. Linda stares at the table. "The doctors give her two years. Maybe three. The brain damage is progressive."

Suddenly the diner feels too hot. Too bright. The fluorescent lights buzz like angry insects.

"I want her to remember being loved. Even if it's not real." Linda looks up. "Even if it's borrowed."

You've implanted false memories before. Rich kids who wanted perfect childhoods. Criminals who needed alibis. Politicians erasing inconvenient truths. But never for someone who wouldn't live long enough to question them.

"The neural patterns won't match. Her brain will reject them."

"Not if you edit them first. Change the biometrics. I've done the research."

Of course she has. Desperate mothers learn things they never wanted to know.

choices.text: "I'll need to see her medical records first."
"Edited memories leave scars. Permanent ones."
"Why not just spend the time you have left with her?"

scenes.title: Planning the Job
scenes.content:
"This Saturday. Midnight to six AM. Three guards total, all on the main floor. Storage vaults are sublevel two."

"Cameras?"

"Motion activated. But I know the blind spots." She slides a hand-drawn map across the table. Surprisingly detailed. "Service elevator here. Emergency stairs here. Vault access requires two keycards and a biometric scan."

"Which you can't provide."

"No. But I know someone who can." She hesitates. "Dr. Harrison. He runs the facility. Has gambling debts. Serious ones."

Everyone has a weakness. Usually money, sex, or fear. Sometimes all three.

"Elena Vasquez's memories are in vault seventeen. Premium storage. Climate controlled, military encryption." Linda traces the path on her map. "In and out in twenty minutes."

Twenty minutes to steal a billionaire's mind. Twenty minutes to set up your daughter for a new life. Twenty minutes to end up dead if something goes wrong.

But the payout would be enormous. Elena's consciousness collection could fund a dozen new identities. New city, new life, new everything.

choices.text: "Set up a meeting with Dr. Harrison."
"I work alone. Find another way."
"What's Elena Vasquez to you?"

scenes.title: Clean Exit
scenes.content:
Marcus meets you at his lab in Echo Park. Former auto shop converted into a memory processing facility. The smell of motor oil still lingers under the antiseptic.

"Celebrity chef. Anton Reyes. Jumped off his balcony yesterday." Marcus hands you a neural storage unit. "Family wants his final day cleaned before the footage leaks. Standard scrub job."

You plug the unit into your equipment. The memories load in fast-forward. Anton waking up. Making coffee. Reading reviews of his latest restaurant. All normal until the afternoon.

Then the memories turn dark. Anton discovering his business partner has been embezzling. His restaurants are bankrupt. His reputation ruined. The final memory shows him standing on his balcony, looking down at the street forty stories below.

"Clean work," Marcus says. "Just edit out the business stuff. Make it look like an accident."

But as you start the editing process, something catches your attention. In the background of Anton's final memory, reflected in his apartment window, you see a woman on the building across the street. Watching through binoculars.

She looks familiar.

scenes.title: Dangerous Game
scenes.content:
You walk back into the diner. Linda looks up, hope flickering in her eyes.

"Someone called me. Warned me off your case." You sit down. "What aren't you telling me?"

"I don't know what you mean."

"Try again."

She's quiet for a long moment. Outside, a police siren wails in the distance. "Sarah wasn't in a car accident."

Of course not.

"She was in a clinical trial. Experimental memory enhancement therapy. My ex-husband signed the consent forms." Linda's voice shakes. "Elena Vasquez was funding it. Testing consciousness transfer technology."

"What went wrong?"

"Nothing went wrong. The experiment worked perfectly. They successfully transferred someone else's consciousness into Sarah's brain." Tears start flowing. "My daughter is gone. Some stranger is wearing her face."

You lean back in the booth. Elena Vasquez. The collector. No wonder someone wants you to back off.

"Whose consciousness?"

"I don't know. But she's not Sarah. She doesn't recognize me. Doesn't act like her. It's like my daughter died and no one will admit it."

choices.text: "We need to get Sarah back. The real one."
"Elena Vasquez needs to pay for this."
"Your daughter's consciousness might still exist somewhere."

scenes.title: The Doctor
scenes.content:
Dr. Harrison meets you at a strip club in Hollywood. Classy place called Velvet Dreams where the drinks cost thirty dollars and nobody asks questions. He's exactly what you expected. Nervous energy, expensive suit, desperate eyes.

"Linda says you have debts," you say.

"Poker. Bad beats." He laughs but there's no humor in it. "Quarter million to some very unfriendly people."

"Elena Vasquez. What do you know about her storage unit?"

"More than I should." He drains his whiskey. "She's not collecting random memories. She's building something. A composite consciousness."

"Explain."

"Take the best parts of different people. A genius scientist's intellect. A war hero's courage. An artist's creativity. Combine them into one super-consciousness." He signals for another drink. "She's trying to achieve immortality by becoming the perfect human."

"And the test subjects?"

"Kids mostly. Their brains are more adaptable. Less likely to reject foreign consciousness patterns." His hands shake as he lights a cigarette. "I helped design the procedure."

Now you understand why Linda's daughter was chosen.

choices.text: "How many other children has she experimented on?"
"I want access to her vault. Tonight."
"You're going to help me stop this."

scenes.title: Breaking In
scenes.content:
Meridian Clinic at three AM looks like a fortress. Black glass and steel, surrounded by security cameras and motion sensors. But Linda was right about the skeleton crew. Only two guards visible, both half-asleep at their desk.

Dr. Harrison's keycard gets you past the main entrance. His biometric scan opens the elevator to sublevel two. The storage vaults stretch out like a high-tech mausoleum. Thousands of memories preserved in liquid nitrogen and digital amber.

Vault seventeen sits at the end of the corridor. Elena Vasquez's private collection. The lock requires Harrison's clearance plus a second authorization you don't have.

"Override code is her birthday," Harrison whispers. "She's that narcissistic."

The vault opens with a soft hiss. Inside, hundreds of memory cores line the walls like bottles of wine. Each one labeled with a name and date. You recognize some of them. Missing persons from the past five years. All between the ages of eight and fifteen.

At the center of the room sits a master storage unit. The composite consciousness Harrison described. Elena's Frankenstein monster made from stolen childhoods.

Then the lights go out.
